Free Retirement Calculator 2025 - Calculate Retirement Savings & Income

Calculate your retirement savings goals, monthly contributions needed, and projected retirement income. Plan your financial future and ensure a comfortable retirement.

How to Use Our Retirement Calculator

  1. Enter Current Age: Input your current age to calculate years until retirement
  2. Set Retirement Age: Choose when you plan to retire (typically 65-67)
  3. Enter Current Savings: Input your existing retirement account balances
  4. Set Monthly Contributions: Enter how much you can save monthly
  5. View Results: See your projected retirement savings and income

Retirement Planning Formula

Your retirement savings are calculated using compound interest:

Future Value = PV × (1 + r)^n + PMT × [((1 + r)^n - 1) / r]

Where: PV = Present value of savings, r = Monthly return rate, n = Number of months until retirement, PMT = Monthly contribution

Frequently Asked Questions

How much should I save for retirement?

A common rule is to save 10-15% of your income for retirement, but the exact amount depends on your age, income, and retirement goals. Use the 4% rule: aim to save 25 times your annual expenses.

What's the difference between 401(k) and IRA accounts?

A 401(k) is an employer-sponsored retirement plan with higher contribution limits, while an IRA is an individual retirement account you open yourself. Both offer tax advantages, but 401(k)s often include employer matching contributions.

When should I start saving for retirement?

The earlier you start, the better due to compound interest. Even starting in your 20s with small amounts can result in significant retirement savings. However, it's never too late to start saving for retirement.

How does inflation affect retirement planning?

Inflation reduces the purchasing power of your money over time. When planning for retirement, consider that expenses will likely be higher in the future, so you may need more savings than current dollar amounts suggest.

What's the 4% retirement withdrawal rule?

The 4% rule suggests you can withdraw 4% of your retirement savings annually without running out of money. This means if you have $1 million saved, you could withdraw $40,000 per year in retirement.

Retirement Calculator Features

  • Savings Goal Planning: Calculate how much you need to save for retirement
  • Monthly Contribution Planning: Determine required monthly savings
  • Income Replacement Analysis: See what percentage of income you'll have in retirement
  • Tax-Advantaged Account Planning: Optimize 401(k) and IRA contributions

Retirement Planning Tips

  • Start saving for retirement as early as possible
  • Take advantage of employer 401(k) matching contributions
  • Maximize contributions to tax-advantaged accounts
  • Diversify your retirement investments across asset classes
  • Consider your expected retirement lifestyle and expenses
  • Plan for healthcare costs in retirement
  • Consider working part-time in retirement to supplement income
  • Review and adjust your retirement plan regularly
